Sub_topics.description: Understand the purpose of the CPU and the stages of the fetch-execute cycle. Be able to describe what actions occur at each stage of the fetch-execute cycle (fetch, decode, execute) at a conceptual level (no requirement to memorise the exact passing of data between registers at each stage).

Know common CPU components and their functions: ALU (Arithmetic Logic Unit), CU (Control Unit), cache, and registers. Understand the role/purpose of each component and what it manages, stores, or controls during the fetch-execute cycle.

Understand Von Neumann architecture CPU registers and their purposes: MAR (Memory Address Register), MDR (Memory Data Register), Program Counter (PC), and Accumulator. For each register, know what it stores (data vs address) and why this matters. Understand the difference between storing data and storing an address/pointer to a memory location.

Understand how CPU characteristics affect performance: clock speed, cache size, and number of cores. Explain the impact of changing each characteristic on system performance, both individually and in combination (e.g. higher clock speed vs larger cache vs more cores and when each helps).

Understand what embedded systems are, their purpose, and typical characteristics (e.g. dedicated function, limited user interface, constraints such as power/memory/processing, reliability). Be familiar with a range of examples of embedded systems in everyday contexts.

Understand why computers need primary storage (memory), typically consisting of RAM and ROM. Know key characteristics of RAM and ROM and the purpose of each in a computer system (RAM as working memory for running programs and data in use; ROM for permanent/firmware/boot instructions).

Understand why virtual memory may be needed when RAM is full and how it works: transfer of data between RAM and secondary storage to allow more programs/data to appear available than fits in RAM (with performance implications).
Understand the role of cache as part of memory hierarchy and how it supports CPU performance by storing frequently used instructions/data closer to the CPU than RAM.

Understand why computers need secondary storage (non-volatile, long-term storage). Recognise a range of storage devices/media and distinguish between optical, magnetic, and solid state storage (no requirement to know internal component parts).

Compare advantages and disadvantages of different secondary storage devices/media using characteristics: capacity, speed, portability, durability, reliability, and cost. Apply knowledge to recommend suitable storage solutions for given scenarios.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Units of data storage and binary requirement
Sub_topics.description: Understand why data must be stored/represented in binary for a computer to process it. Know data storage units and conversions: bit, nibble (4 bits), byte (8 bits), kilobyte (1,000 bytes or 1 KB), megabyte (1,000 KB), gigabyte (1,000 MB), terabyte (1,000 GB), petabyte (1,000 TB). (Alternative acceptable: use 1,024-based conversions.)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: File size and storage capacity calculations
Sub_topics.description: Calculate required storage capacity for a given set of files and understand that storage devices have fixed capacities. Calculate file sizes using: sound file size = sample rate × duration(s) × bit depth; image file size = colour depth × image height(px) × image width(px); text file size = bits per character × number of characters. (Allowance may be made for metadata; 1,024-based calculations acceptable.)

Convert positive denary whole numbers to binary and vice versa, up to and including 8 bits (denary range 0–255; binary range 00000000–11111111). Be able to handle numbers with 1–8 bits (e.g. 11010 == 00011010). Understand most significant bit (MSB) and least significant bit (LSB).
Add two binary integers (up to and including 8 bits) and explain overflow errors that occur when the result exceeds the available bit length (8-bit overflow).

Convert positive denary whole numbers to 2-digit hexadecimal numbers and vice versa (hex range 00–FF). Convert binary integers to hexadecimal equivalents and vice versa within the 8-bit range. Be able to convert any number in the specified ranges between bases.
Understand and perform binary shifts left and right on binary numbers (up to 8 bits). Explain the effect of a left shift or right shift on the value represented.

Understand how characters are represented in binary using character codes and the meaning of 'character set'. Explain the relationship between bits per character and how many characters can be represented. Compare ASCII and Unicode and their impacts/uses. Understand that character sets are logically ordered (e.g. code('B') = code('A') + 1). ASCII representation in exam uses 8 bits; memorisation of specific codes is not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Image representation, resolution, colour depth, metadata
Sub_topics.description: Understand how an image is represented as pixels with colours stored as binary codes. Explain effects of changing colour depth and resolution on image quality and file size. Understand metadata as additional stored information about an image (e.g. width, height, etc.).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Sound sampling: sample rate, duration, bit depth
Sub_topics.description: Understand how analogue sound is sampled and stored digitally in binary. Know sample rate measured in Hertz (Hz), duration in seconds, and bit depth (bits per sample, e.g. 16-bit). Explain how sample rate, duration and bit depth affect playback quality and file size.

Understand why compression is needed in common scenarios (e.g. storage limits, faster transmission). Compare lossy and lossless compression, including advantages, disadvantages, and effects on the file. (Not required: carrying out specific compression algorithms.)
Understand characteristics of LAN (Local Area Network) and WAN (Wide Area Network) and give common examples of each.
Understand factors affecting network performance such as number of devices connected and bandwidth, and apply these to scenarios.
Understand the different roles of computers in client-server and peer-to-peer networks and apply differences to given contexts (e.g. central management and services vs equal peers).

Know the hardware needed to connect stand-alone computers into a LAN and the tasks performed by each: wireless access points, routers, switches, NIC (Network Interface Controller/Card), and transmission media.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: The Internet, DNS, hosting, servers, clients, and the Cloud
Sub_topics.description: Understand the Internet as a worldwide collection of computer networks. Understand that a Domain Name Service (DNS) is made up of multiple Domain Name Servers and its role converting a URL to an IP address. Understand hosting and that servers provide services (e.g. web server provides web pages; file server provides storage/retrieval) and clients request/use these services. Understand the Cloud as remote service provision (e.g. storage, software, processing) and evaluate advantages and disadvantages of cloud computing.

Understand and compare star and mesh network topologies, including advantages and disadvantages of each, and apply understanding to scenario-based questions (e.g. resilience, cabling cost, performance, single points of failure).

Compare benefits and drawbacks of wired (Ethernet) versus wireless connections (Wi‑Fi, Bluetooth). Recommend appropriate connection type(s) for given scenarios. (Not required: detailed understanding of how Ethernet/Wi‑Fi/Bluetooth protocols work.)
Understand the principle of encryption to secure data across network connections (confidentiality during transmission).
Understand IP addressing and the format of an IP address for IPv4 and IPv6. (Not required: static vs dynamic or public vs private distinctions.)
Understand that MAC addresses are assigned to devices, their use within a network, and the format of a MAC address.

Understand the principle of a standard as a set of rules in computing and that standards allow hardware/software to interact across different manufacturers/producers. (Not required: knowledge of individual named standards.)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Protocols: TCP/IP, HTTP(S), FTP, POP, IMAP, SMTP
Sub_topics.description: Understand the principle of a communication protocol as a set of rules for transferring data; that different protocols serve different purposes; and the basic principles/purpose and key features of: TCP/IP, HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, POP, IMAP, and SMTP.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Protocol layering concept (TCP/IP model as example)
Sub_topics.description: Understand how layers are used in protocols and the benefits of using layers (e.g. abstraction, interoperability, easier troubleshooting/development). Use the 4-layer TCP/IP model as a teaching example conceptually. (Not required: names and functions of each TCP/IP layer.)
Understand threats posed to devices, computer systems and networks and the principles behind common attack methods (how used and purpose).
Understand malware as a form of attack, including how it is used to compromise systems (e.g. damage, disruption, data theft, unauthorised access) and the attacker’s purpose.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Social engineering (phishing) and humans as weak point
Sub_topics.description: Understand social engineering attacks such as phishing and the idea that people can be the ‘weak point’ in security. Know how such attacks work (deception to obtain credentials/data) and their purpose.
Understand brute-force attacks (systematic guessing of passwords/keys), how they are carried out, and their purpose (unauthorised access).
Understand denial of service attacks, how they overwhelm services or networks to prevent legitimate use, and their purpose/impact on availability.
Understand attacks involving data interception (e.g. capturing data in transit) and theft, including how data can be obtained and the purpose (confidentiality breach, fraud, identity theft).
Understand the concept of SQL injection as an attack where malicious input targets database queries to access, modify, or delete data, bypass authentication, or otherwise compromise a system.

Understand how to limit the threats in 1.4.1 and methods to remove vulnerabilities. For each prevention method, know what it limits/prevents and how it limits the attack: penetration testing, anti-malware software, firewalls, user access levels, passwords, encryption, and physical security.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Operating system purpose and user interface
Sub_topics.description: Understand the purpose of an operating system (OS) and OS user interface functionality. Know features of a user interface and how the OS provides interaction between user/applications and hardware.
Understand OS memory management: transfer of data between memory, allocation of memory to applications, and how this enables multitasking. (Not required: paging or segmentation.)

Understand peripheral management and drivers: that data is transferred between devices and the processor and this process needs to be managed by the OS; drivers enable OS/software to communicate with hardware peripherals.
Understand OS user management functions such as allocation of user accounts, access rights/permissions, and security controls.
Understand OS file management and key features such as naming files, organising into folders/directories, moving files, and saving/storing files.

Understand that computers often come with utility software which performs housekeeping/maintenance tasks and that utility software is needed to perform additional tasks that may not be carried out by an operating system.
Understand the purpose and functionality of utility system software including encryption software, defragmentation, and data compression software, and why each is required.

Topics.Topic_name: Ethical, legal, cultural and environmental impacts of digital technology

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impacts of digital technology on society
Sub_topics.description: Understand that digital technology introduces ethical, legal, cultural, environmental and privacy issues. Know a variety of examples of digital technologies and be able to discuss their impacts on individuals and wider society across these issue areas, giving balanced, contextualised points.

Understand the purpose of the Data Protection Act 2018 and the specific actions it allows or prohibits in relation to personal data handling (e.g. responsibilities of organisations processing personal data and individuals’ rights).
Understand the purpose of the Computer Misuse Act 1990 and the specific actions it prohibits (e.g. unauthorised access, unauthorised modification, and related computer misuse offences).

Understand the purpose of the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 and the specific actions it allows or prohibits regarding use/copying/distribution of copyrighted works including software and digital media.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Software licences: open source vs proprietary
Sub_topics.description: Understand why software is licensed and the purpose of a software licence. Know features of open source software (access to source code and ability to change/modify) and proprietary software (no access to source code; commonly purchased off-the-shelf). Be able to recommend a suitable licence type for a scenario, including benefits and drawbacks.

Understand principles of computational thinking and how they are used to define and refine problems: abstraction (removing unnecessary detail), decomposition (breaking into sub-problems), and algorithmic thinking (creating step-by-step solutions).
Be able to identify the inputs, processes, and outputs required for a given problem and use this to plan an algorithm/solution.
Produce simple structure diagrams to show the structure of a problem, its subsections/modules, and the links between subsections (supporting decomposition and program design).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Algorithms in pseudocode, flowcharts, and code
Sub_topics.description: Create, interpret, correct, complete, and refine algorithms using pseudocode, flowcharts, and reference language/high-level programming language. Use nesting appropriately for selection and iteration. Understand standard flowchart symbols: line/arrow (flow), input/output, process, decision, subprogram, and terminal.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Common errors and debugging (syntax vs logic)
Sub_topics.description: Identify common errors in algorithms/code including syntax and logic errors and suggest fixes, demonstrating understanding of correct program flow and intended outcomes.
Create and use trace tables to follow the execution of an algorithm step-by-step, tracking variable values and outputs to understand or debug behaviour.

Understand the main steps and code structure/segments of standard searching algorithms: linear search and binary search. Understand any prerequisites (e.g. binary search requires sorted data). Apply each algorithm to a data set and identify an algorithm from given code/pseudocode/OCR Exam Reference Language (no requirement to memorise exact code listings).

Understand the main steps and code structure/segments of standard sorting algorithms: bubble sort, merge sort, and insertion sort. Apply each algorithm to a data set and identify an algorithm from given code/pseudocode/OCR Exam Reference Language (no requirement to memorise exact code listings).
Use variables and constants, inputs and outputs, operators and assignment statements in a high-level language. Understand what variables/constants represent and how assignment updates stored values.

Understand and use the three basic programming constructs to control flow: sequence; selection; iteration including count-controlled loops and condition-controlled loops. Apply these constructs to solve problems using a high-level language.

Recognise and use common operators. Comparison: ==, !=, <, <=, >, >=. Arithmetic: +, –, *, /, MOD (modulo), DIV (quotient/integer division), ^ (exponentiation). Boolean: AND, OR, NOT. Apply operators correctly within expressions and conditions.

Use and choose suitable data types: integer, real, Boolean, character, string. Understand that casting can temporarily convert a value to another data type and explain where this is useful (e.g. converting input strings to numbers for arithmetic).
Use basic string manipulation in programs, including concatenation and slicing (extracting substrings).
Use basic file handling operations: open, read, write, close. Understand typical program flow for sequential file processing (open → read/write loop → close).
Understand and use records (or equivalent structures) to store related data fields together, and apply this when modelling structured data in programs.
Use SQL to search for data using commands SELECT, FROM, and WHERE. Understand how conditions in WHERE filter records and how fields are chosen in SELECT.

Use arrays (or equivalent) to solve problems, including one-dimensional (1D) and two-dimensional (2D) arrays. Understand arrays as fixed-length/static structures. Use 2D arrays to emulate database tables consisting of fields and records (rows/columns).

Use subprograms (functions and procedures) to produce structured, maintainable code. Understand the difference between procedures and functions (returning a value). Know when to use each effectively. Use local variables/constants and global variables/constants appropriately. Pass arrays into subprograms and return arrays/values where appropriate.
Create and use random numbers in a program (e.g. for simulation, games, sampling), understanding the effect of chosen bounds and integer vs real outputs depending on language constructs.
Understand defensive design considerations when developing programs, including anticipating misuse and designing for all likely input values and user behaviours to reduce errors and vulnerabilities.

Understand authentication as confirming the identity of a user. Gain practical experience designing simple authentication systems (e.g. username and password) and understanding their role in security.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Input validation and handling invalid data
Sub_topics.description: Design and implement input validation to ensure data is reasonable/acceptable. Understand how to detect and deal with invalid data in a program (e.g. rejecting, re-prompting, error messages).

Understand maintainability and apply good practice: use of subprograms, clear naming conventions, consistent indentation, and appropriate commenting. Understand why commenting is useful and apply it appropriately.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Purpose of testing and test stages
Sub_topics.description: Understand the purpose of testing and distinguish between iterative testing (testing modules during development) and final/terminal testing (testing the complete program at the end of production).

Identify syntax errors (breaking grammatical rules of the language, preventing running/translation) and logic errors (program runs but produces unexpected output). Be able to locate and correct both types.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Test data: normal, boundary, invalid, erroneous
Sub_topics.description: Select suitable test data and justify choices: normal data (valid and should be accepted), boundary data (valid type at the edge of validity), invalid data (correct type but should be rejected), erroneous data (incorrect data type and should be rejected). Apply to given input constraints and scenarios.
Create and complete a test plan (test cases, inputs, expected outputs, actual outputs, pass/fail) and use results to refine algorithms/programs to improve correctness and robustness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Logic gates and symbols (AND, OR, NOT)
Sub_topics.description: Recognise logic gate symbols and understand simple logic diagrams using AND (conjunction), OR (disjunction) and NOT (negation). Be able to create, complete, and edit logic diagrams for given scenarios, including circuits with more than one gate.
Know and use the truth tables for AND, OR, and NOT. Apply logical operators in truth tables to solve problems. Accept equivalent notation such as T/F for 1/0 or ∨ for OR.
Combine Boolean operators AND, OR, and NOT in expressions and evaluate outputs using truth tables and reasoning for multi-gate logic problems.

Topics.Topic_name: Programming languages and Integrated Development Environments

Sub_topics.description: Understand characteristics and purposes of different levels of programming language: high-level languages (more abstraction, portability, readability) and low-level languages (closer to hardware, less abstraction). Explain key differences and implications for development and performance.

Understand the need for translators to convert source code into a form a computer can execute. Compare compilers and interpreters, including how they work at a high level, and benefits/drawbacks of each (e.g. speed, error reporting, portability). (Not required: assemblers.)

Know common tools/facilities provided by an Integrated Development Environment (IDE): editors, error diagnostics, run-time environment, and translators. Explain how each helps a programmer develop programs and have practical experience using a range of these tools within at least one IDE.
